trans-unit.source: App Model v2.0 | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: App Model v2.0 | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: How to build a .NET MVC Web App that calls web services using personal Microsoft accounts and work or school accounts for sign-in.
trans-unit.target: How to build a .NET MVC Web App that calls web services using personal Microsoft accounts and work or school accounts for sign-in.

trans-unit.source: This information applies to the v2.0 endpoint public preview.
trans-unit.target: This information applies to the v2.0 endpoint public preview.

trans-unit.source: For instructions on how to integrate with the generally available Azure AD service, please refer to the <linkText>Azure Active Directory Developer Guide</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For instructions on how to integrate with the generally available Azure AD service, please refer to the <linkText>Azure Active Directory Developer Guide</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: With the v2.0 app model, you can quickly add authentication to your web apps and web APIs with support for both personal Microsoft accounts and work or school accounts.
trans-unit.target: With the v2.0 app model, you can quickly add authentication to your web apps and web APIs with support for both personal Microsoft accounts and work or school accounts.

trans-unit.source: Here, we'll build an MVC web app that:
trans-unit.target: Here, we'll build an MVC web app that:

trans-unit.source: Signs users in using OpenID Connect, with some help from Microsoft's OWIN middleware.
trans-unit.target: Signs users in using OpenID Connect, with some help from Microsoft's OWIN middleware.

trans-unit.source: Gets OAuth 2.0 access tokens for a web API using ADAL.
trans-unit.target: Gets OAuth 2.0 access tokens for a web API using ADAL.

trans-unit.source: Creates, Reads, and Deletes items on a user's "To-Do List", which is hosted on the web api and secured by OAuth 2.0.
trans-unit.target: Creates, Reads, and Deletes items on a user's "To-Do List", which is hosted on the web api and secured by OAuth 2.0.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial will focus primarily on getting and using access tokens in a web app, described in full <linkText>here</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial will focus primarily on getting and using access tokens in a web app, described in full <linkText>here</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: As prerequisites, you may want to first learn how to <linkText>add basic sign-in to a web app</linkText><title></title> or how to <linkText>properly secure a web API</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: As prerequisites, you may want to first learn how to <linkText>add basic sign-in to a web app</linkText><title></title> or how to <linkText>properly secure a web API</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The basic steps to call the To-Do List Web API from the client are:
trans-unit.target: The basic steps to call the To-Do List Web API from the client are:

trans-unit.source: Register an app
trans-unit.target: Register an app

trans-unit.source: Sign the user into the web app using OpenID Connect
trans-unit.target: Sign the user into the web app using OpenID Connect

trans-unit.source: Use ADAL to get an access token upon user sign-in
trans-unit.target: Use ADAL to get an access token upon user sign-in

trans-unit.source: Call the To-Do List Web API with an access token.
trans-unit.target: Call the To-Do List Web API with an access token.

trans-unit.source: The code for this tutorial is maintained <linkText>on GitHub</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: The code for this tutorial is maintained <linkText>on GitHub</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: To follow along, you can <linkText>download the app's skeleton as a .zip</linkText><title></title> or clone the skeleton:
trans-unit.target: To follow along, you can <linkText>download the app's skeleton as a .zip</linkText><title></title> or clone the skeleton:

trans-unit.source: PM> Install-Package Microsoft.Owin.Security.OpenIdConnect -ProjectName TodoList-WebApp PM> Install-Package Microsoft.Owin.Security.Cookies -ProjectName TodoList-WebApp PM> Install-Package Microsoft.Owin.Host.SystemWeb -ProjectName TodoList-WebApp
trans-unit.target: PM> Install-Package Microsoft.Owin.Security.OpenIdConnect -ProjectName TodoList-WebApp PM> Install-Package Microsoft.Owin.Security.Cookies -ProjectName TodoList-WebApp PM> Install-Package Microsoft.Owin.Host.SystemWeb -ProjectName TodoList-WebApp

trans-unit.source: In the AuthorizationCodeReceived notification, we want to use OAuth 2.0 in tandem with OpenID Connect to redeem the authorization_code for an access token to the To-Do List Service.
trans-unit.target: In the AuthorizationCodeReceived notification, we want to use OAuth 2.0 in tandem with OpenID Connect to redeem the authorization_code for an access token to the To-Do List Service.

trans-unit.source: ADAL can make this process easy for you:
trans-unit.target: ADAL can make this process easy for you:

trans-unit.source: First, install the preview version of ADAL:
trans-unit.target: First, install the preview version of ADAL:

trans-unit.source: In web apps, ADAL has an extensible token cache that can be used to store tokens.
trans-unit.target: In web apps, ADAL has an extensible token cache that can be used to store tokens.

trans-unit.source: This sample implements the NaiveSessionCache which uses http session storage to cache tokens.
trans-unit.target: This sample implements the NaiveSessionCache which uses http session storage to cache tokens.

trans-unit.source: Now it's time to actually use the access_token you acquired in step 3.
trans-unit.target: Now it's time to actually use the access_token you acquired in step 3.

trans-unit.source: Open the web app's Controllers\TodoListController.cs file, which makes all the CRUD requests to the To-Do List API.
trans-unit.target: Open the web app's Controllers\TodoListController.cs file, which makes all the CRUD requests to the To-Do List API.

trans-unit.source: You can use ADAL again here to fetch access_tokens from the ADAL cache.
trans-unit.target: You can use ADAL again here to fetch access_tokens from the ADAL cache.

trans-unit.source: First, add a using statement for ADAL to this file.
trans-unit.target: First, add a using statement for ADAL to this file.

trans-unit.source: using Microsoft.Experimental.IdentityModel.Clients.ActiveDirectory;
trans-unit.target: using Microsoft.Experimental.IdentityModel.Clients.ActiveDirectory;

trans-unit.source: In the Index action, use ADAL's AcquireTokenSilentAsync method to get an access_token that can be used to read data from the To-Do List service:
trans-unit.target: In the Index action, use ADAL's AcquireTokenSilentAsync method to get an access_token that can be used to read data from the To-Do List service:

trans-unit.source: The sample then adds the resulting token to the HTTP GET request as the Authorization header, which the To-Do List service uses to authenticate the request.
trans-unit.target: The sample then adds the resulting token to the HTTP GET request as the Authorization header, which the To-Do List service uses to authenticate the request.

trans-unit.source: If the To-Do List service returns a 401 Unauthorized response, the access_tokens in ADAL have become invalid for some reason.
trans-unit.target: If the To-Do List service returns a 401 Unauthorized response, the access_tokens in ADAL have become invalid for some reason.

trans-unit.source: In this case, you should drop any access_tokens from the ADAL cache and show the user a message that they may need to sign in again, which will restart the token acquisition flow.
trans-unit.target: In this case, you should drop any access_tokens from the ADAL cache and show the user a message that they may need to sign in again, which will restart the token acquisition flow.

trans-unit.source: Similarly, if ADAL is unable to return an access_token for any reason, you should instruct the user to sign in again.
trans-unit.target: Similarly, if ADAL is unable to return an access_token for any reason, you should instruct the user to sign in again.

trans-unit.source: This is as simple as catching any AdalException:
trans-unit.target: This is as simple as catching any AdalException:

trans-unit.source: The exact same AcquireTokenSilentAsync call is implementd in the Create and Delete actions.
trans-unit.target: The exact same AcquireTokenSilentAsync call is implementd in the Create and Delete actions.

trans-unit.source: In web apps, you can use this ADAL method to get access_tokens whenever you need them in your app.
trans-unit.target: In web apps, you can use this ADAL method to get access_tokens whenever you need them in your app.

trans-unit.source: ADAL will take care of acquiring, caching, and refreshing tokens for you.
trans-unit.target: ADAL will take care of acquiring, caching, and refreshing tokens for you.

trans-unit.source: Finally, build and run your app! Sign in with either a Microsoft Account or an Azure AD Account, and notice how the user's identity is reflected in the top navigation bar. Add and delete some items from the user's To-Do List to see the OAuth 2.0 secured API calls in action. You now have a web app & web API, both secured using industry standard protocols, that can authenticate users with both their personal and work/school accounts.
trans-unit.target: Finally, build and run your app! Sign in with either a Microsoft Account or an Azure AD Account, and notice how the user's identity is reflected in the top navigation bar. Add and delete some items from the user's To-Do List to see the OAuth 2.0 secured API calls in action. You now have a web app & web API, both secured using industry standard protocols, that can authenticate users with both their personal and work/school accounts.

trans-unit.source: For reference, the completed sample (without your configuration values) <linkText>is provided here</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For reference, the completed sample (without your configuration values) <linkText>is provided here</linkText><title></title>.
